direction.raw_text: Blue sky, a few puffs of cloud, pierced by slanting rays of sunlight. Late afternoon on a perfect day.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : "HOUSTON, TEXAS. JULY 4, 2020." As we hear, after a few more beats, an ASTRONAUT'S VOICE.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A tiny red streak zips into the sky, then bursts with a faint, ludicrous POP. A bottle rocket. We hear CHILDREN'S LAUGHTER, excited SHOUTS.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: T minus ten, nine, eight, start ignition sequence, five, four, three, two, one, ignition... Liftoff!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . LUKE GRAHAM'S HOUSE. LATE AFTERNOON DESCENDING, we see PHIL OHLMYER, late 20's, kneeling, with a gaggle of eager CHILDREN around him. Phil, an astronaut, has got an impressive array of fireworks lined up, and is using an empty longneck as his launching tube.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Derisive GROANS from the kids, more SHOUTS. Phil grins. There's little danger NASA will ever use him on a recruiting poster: he's messy, very hyper. Phil waves his hands for silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Another astronaut, RENEE COTE, a tall, very fit French woman, is walking by with a fresh six-pack. She tosses a beer and Phil catches it.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (all at once) My turn! My turn! No, I was next! No, me! Uncle Phil, Uncle Phil, can I do one? I want to do one!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Guys, guys, please! This is risky stuff here. And I'm a highly trained professional.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Okay, okay! Uncle Phil will launch another booster...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...just as soon as he completes his fuel intake.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: FOLLOWS COTE Who grins, walking away from Phil and the kids, as we begin to get a better sense of the scope of this party. We are in the big back yard of a middle-class home in a Houston suburb. DOZENS OF PEOPLE - astronauts, NASA personnel, and their families -- are gathered around picnic tables or spread-out blankets. Lots of red, white and blue bunting, lots of balloons. We hear snatches of MUSIC, mostly country-flavored, from dueling boomboxes. Futuristic Frisbees are being tossed about. A banner, strung between trees, reads "BON VOYAGE, MARS ONE!!!"
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Passing the banner, Cote lobs a beer to another astronaut, NICHOLAS WILLIS, who snags it neatly. He's got his other arm around the waist of a PRETTY GIRL. As Cote moves OUT OF FRAME, ANGLE LINGERS on these two. Willis, a very young astronaut, early 20s, is recruiting poster material, and knows it all too well.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As the Pretty Girl slips out of his grasp, laughing, and walks away, Willis shrugs philosophically. He pops open his beer, swigs it.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: It'll take us six months just to get to Mars. Another year on the surface, then six months back. That's two years...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I guess what I'm trying to say is, since this is my last night on Earth, it's gonna be a very precious memory to me. Y'know?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nice try, Nick.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: FOLLOWS THE PRETTY GIRL As she swerves around an open- pit barbecue, where other ASTRONAUTS are gathered. Cote has paused here, too, distributing the last of her beers. SERGEI KIROV, a Russian cosmonaut, is watching some kids nearby as they play a game of wiffle ball. He turns, grinning beerily at the chef.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, Woody, our Mars One crew won't be heading back to Earth till ten days after you guys land at our base camp with Mars Two. That's a pretty good long rendezvous.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: late 30s, is a big, rangy guy in a cowboy hat over a Hawaiian shirt and a "KISS THE CHEF" apron. An entire pig is turning on a spit over the flames, and Woody is basting this as he smiles at Malik.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He grins teasingly at Cote, who makes a face at him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What are you suggesting, Sergei?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe you should bring a baseball bat. Yes? American baseball? Our two crews could have ourselves a little Solar System Series.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Please. Half you guys are foreigners. We'd crush you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, no, we have equal crews. Three men, one woman. Same handicap.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Easy now, you're talking about my wife. (seeing her approach) And Terri just happens to be one helluva shortstop.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . TERRI FISHER, early 30s, passes by with a platter of corn-on-the-cob. Short, sturdy body, a face made attractive by its alert, questing intelligence. She pauses to kiss Woody's cheek; there's a wonderful, sexy spark between them. Then she glances at Kirov, all business now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's a bit rattled by her cockiness, and looks at Cote, who smiles, nods her cool agreement.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The other men ooooh at this, busting on Kirov and Cote, as Terri moves on. Woody, watching her go, has a thousand-watt grin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The others laugh.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Fast pitch, no steals, batter calls his own strikes. Thousand bucks make it interesting?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Eh bien. Winner take all.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good. (smiles sweetly at Kirov) Bring some balls.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You wanna know the sad part? Technically I outrank her. But if we want any peace at all on Mars Two, I'm gonna be saying a lot of "Yes, dears."
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: FOLLOWS TERRI as she dodges a PACK OF KIDS -- they run by her, shrieking happily - before she finally reaches a picnic table, where ASTRONAUTS' WIVES are opening containers of baked beans, coleslaw, and potato salad.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: One of the other women raises a warning eyebrow, and the 1st Wife turns, sees Terri setting down her platter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Laughter at this. Terri smiles politely -- she doesn't really have much in common with these women -- before moving on. ANGLE LINGERS on the wives, who watch her go with a slight tinge of jealousy. One of them is looking around.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She shakes her head, awed by the thought. The others nod in agreement, following her glance... In the distance, a lone MALE FIGURE stands by the garage, his back to them, facing the parked cars, vans, and SUVs which stretch down the driveway and along the street. Another figure, a WOMAN, can be seen approaching him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: ...just not sure how I feel about NASA allowing couples to go on this type of mission together.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (embarrassed) Nothing personal, Terri. It's just that, well, it's kind of a funny feeling for those of us staying behind.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (carefully neutral) All the research shows that marriage will provide stability on these long duration trips.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then they haven't studied some of the couples I've known.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Anybody seen Jim McConnell?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't think he's coming.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: God, that poor man. How's he doing?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Totally losing it, from what I hear. Can't sleep, can't eat. Visits her grave almost every day. (lowers her voice) They say he could lose mission status.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, that's so sad. That is just so tragic. You go to a routine physical one day, and wham.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: After all those years of training, too. It was their whole dream.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Must be a pretty funny feeling for Luke Graham. Y'know? Now he's gonna be in the history books. First man on Mars...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: R ANGLE FOLLOWS the moving woman -- DEBRA GRAHAM, early 30s, very attractive -- until she reaches her husband. LUKE GRAHAM, mid 30s, has the lean, fit body of an astronaut, the restless intellect of a scientist. He's unaware of her approach until she touches his shoulder. He looks at her with an apologetic smile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks at her, moved. She summons a smile. He slides his arms around her waist, kisses her forehead.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He kisses her again, then goes. Debra's eyes follow him, with a mixture of pride and sadness.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: He's not coming, Luke.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Jim deserves this, too. All his friends are here. And it's my last night.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (gently) Your last night with us, too.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I love you, Deb.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I love you too, baby. But maybe you should spend some time with Bobby.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah. I will. Where is he?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Up in his fort.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: FOLLOWS Luke away from the garage, into
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . LATE AFTERNOON Luke moves through the crowd. Phil and the kids are still shooting off rockets. Red streaks arc high overhead. In the back corner of the yard, where it's quieter, he passes Willis, who's sitting on a blanket, murmuring soulfully to PRETTY GIRL #2.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Luke shakes his head. Willis is incorrigible. Finally he reaches a tall redwood playset. He looks up the ladder.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Deep space is so lonesome. So cold. But I guess I'll have my memories to keep me warm...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: sits on the platform of the tower, arms around his knees, staring up at the stars. A telescope rests nearby on a tripod. He looks lonely. Luke climbs up, sits down on the wooden deck next to him. BOBBY, 7, glances over at his dad, his idol, then back at the sky.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Luke is surprised by the question. A pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His voice is unexpectedly fierce. He's fighting back tears. Luke is moved. Another brief silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bobby manages a smile. He nods, feeling a little better. Luke is proud of his son's courage.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bobby's arms go around his father's neck. He hugs Luke fiercely, and Luke hugs him back. His eyes, over the thin young shoulders, are brimming with love and impending absence. Then, from the distance, the sound of an APPROACHING CAR. They both turn. An open Jeep is coming down the street. Its DRIVER is alone. Luke's expression changes. Recognition, then happiness.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Who's gonna read to me now, at bedtime?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mommy will.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I like when you do it. Now we're never gonna finish our book.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I'll tell you what. I've been thinking about that. And what I thought was -- how 'bout if I bring along my own copy? (Bobby looks at him) Then every night, wherever I am, I'll read a little bit more of it. And I'll know that you and Mommy, wherever you are, you're reading it too. That way, it'll feel like we're still reading it together. 'Cause I don't know about you, but I'm pretty anxious to find out how 'ol Ben Gunn got marooned on that island. What d'you say?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good deal. Can I have a hug?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . LATE AFTERNOON The Jeep stops, its electric engine WHIRRING down. The Driver climbs out wearily, reaching into the back seat, and comes out with a champagne bottle, hastily decorated with ribbon. The PARTY SOUNDS are drifting this way, and he hesitates a moment, seeming to gather himself. He starts gamely towards the party, then pauses again. Debra Graham stands nearby on the front lawn, waiting. She smiles tentatively.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: early 40s, manages a smile in return. He has dark circles under his eyes, and his clothes look slept in. Yet we sense, even through his sadness, a kind of quiet competence in this man, an unforced authority; he's a natural leader. Debra hurries forward, into his arms, and he hugs her. They separate, looking at each other. Her eyes are shining.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Over her shoulder he sees Luke approaching, his arm around Bobby. The two men look at each other, the bond between them so strong it needs no words. Finally Luke smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: McConnell comes towards him, accompanied by Debra, and together the four of them move OUT OF FRAME, heading towards the party. ANGLE HOLDS on the parking area, as we...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: We were afraid you wouldn't come.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I caught a whiff of your barbecue. After that I was helpless.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All the way out in Galveston?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Something like that. (she smiles) It's his night, Deb. I didn't want to spoil it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Spoil it? He's been going crazy looking for you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: C'mon. A whole lot of folks here are gonna be mighty glad to see you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT (HOURS LATER) All the parked cars and vans are gone now, except for two: McConnell's Jeep and Woody's classic 'Vette. Willis, one of the last to go, is just departing on his motorcycle. Perched behind him, arms around his waist, is PRETTY GIRL #3. They zoom away, through the darkened neighborhood.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT The yard is nearly deserted. The "Bon Voyage" banner has torn loose at one end and flutters limply. Here and there a napkin blows across the ground. In the distance, THREE FIGURES sit on the ground, by the waning fire of the barbecue pit, sipping beers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: R ON THIS TRIO As Woody shoves another piece of wood into the flames. For a moment he, McConnell, and Luke are silent, staring at the sparks as they rise towards the stars -- red and gold dots mingling with the silver ones.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The intensity in his voice surprises the others, and even Woody himself. Luke glances at McConnell. An awkward beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He grabs playfully at Woody's neck. Woody smacks his hand away, laughing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He pulls from his shirt a little Flash Gordon rocketship emblem hanging on a chain, and waggles this tauntingly at McConnell, as Luke and McConnell laugh.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Luke grabs Woody's arm to give McConnell a better shot at the emblem, but Woody cuffs his hands away, laughing. McConnell, watching their horseplay, shakes his head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He tries to smile, but his face reddens. Then all at once his chest is heaving as he struggles to control his emotions. Woody sees this, reaches out a reassuring hand, but McConnell shakes him off, rises abruptly. He turns his back on them, walking away a few steps. Woody and Luke exchange a worried glance.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (abruptly) I wish we were all going. Together.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then you've got a short memory. Think back to how we were by the second week of lunar training.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, you're not gonna bring that up again -- LUKE (laughing) I'm trying to remember, let's see, which one of us scored the lowest ranking up there?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You just can't let that go -- LUKE Oh, man, three commanders, on the same ship? If they sent us off to Mars together, there wouldn't be enough fuel to lift all those egos.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (laughs) Bullshit, we would've made a great crew.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That was never gonna happen. I was always teamed with Maggie, and we were mostly chalkboard jockies. You know? Systems. Payloads...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Listen to him. Mr. Cover-of-Time Magazine!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, who landed the crippled Block II Shuttle?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, and who scored highest on the lunar rankings?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Let it go, Luke.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (smiles) Sure, I made a little noise. But putting the first footprints on Mars? Nah. That's for guys who... (looks at Luke) ...wrote their Ph.D. thesis on how to colonize the place. And guys who... (looks at Woody) ...read too much science fiction as a kid and still wear little Flash Gordon rocketships around their necks.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You read the same damn science fiction books that I did! You're just not man enough to wear jewelry!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You want Flash. You know you want him. Well you'll have to come through me!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: God, she would've loved to see you two clowns. Just one more time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . LATER THAT NIGHT McConnell and Luke watch as Woody starts up his Corvette. McConnell has regained his composure.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Woody revs the engine, which ROARS lustily. He grins.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Luke laughs. Woody looks at McConnell.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Woody reaches out to shake Luke's hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: With a final glance at McConnell, Woody slips the car into gear. McConnell and Luke watch as he drives away. A silence. Luke glances at his old friend, growing more serious. We sense he's been waiting all night for a chance to say this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: McConnell, looking after Woody's car, becomes very still.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: McConnell turns to him, his eyes flashing danger. He will not tolerate pity. Luke sees this but presses on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: McConnell is deeply moved, and for a moment doesn't trust his own voice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Luke nods. They grab hands for a second, then let go. Luke walks back towards his house. McConnell watches him for a moment, then turns, walks over to his Jeep. He opens his door, then pauses. He turns. Looks up at -- EXT. NIGHT SKY A tiny reddish dot hovers there, glowing steadily. Mars itself, a tantalizing prize. But for him now, more distant than ever. For him, perhaps, never to be attained.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, Woodrow, isn't it about time you donated this thing to a museum?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Internal combustion, boys. Accept no substitutes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Jim, if there's ever... if there's anything Terri and I can do -- MCCONNELL I'm okay. Really. Thanks.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: See you when I get to Mars, Luke. Don't solve all the mysteries of the universe, okay? Leave a little something for the next guys.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll see what I can do. Just make sure you bring some fresh beer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You got it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Should've been your mission, Jim. Yours and Maggie's.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: None of us ever wanted Mars the way you two did. Not even Woody. Twelve years of hoping for this assignment, training for it -- MCCONNELL That's all over now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If Maggie hadn't gotten sick -- if you hadn't pulled yourself out of the rotation to take care of her --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, I'm gonna say this. I have to say it... (pause) I wanted Mars One. Hell, I battled you for it every step of the way. Never wanted to beat anybody so bad in my life. But not like this... Jim, I'd give this all up in a second, if it would bring Maggie back to us.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know that, Luke. You don't have to say it... Mars is yours now. Go get it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (pause) Take care of yourself.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah. You too.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: As we see these thoughts going through him. After a moment he looks down at
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And the sandy verge of the front yard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are a map of complex emotions: regret, injured pride, infinite yearning. Gently, a bit self-consciously, HE LIFTS ONE SHOE And sets it down again, making a careful, deliberate footprint in the sandy soil...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sequence omitted from original script.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CHRYSE PLANITIA. DAY Instantly we're hurled into an immense, stunning LANDSCAPE, mysterious and vivid as a fever dream. Dazzling sunlight. A vast plain of rust-orange soil. Countless craters. Boulders the size of houses, tossed about by the hands of gods. Twin moons hanging in a salmon-pink sky. On the horizon, towering, craggy peaks. And, at center -- the only sign of life -- a small, mysterious, moving puff of dust.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sequence omitted from original script.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY CLOSER ANGLE as a small, Sojourner-like, multi-wheeled robotic vehicle ambles INTO FRAME, jouncing along the orange Martian soil, pausing to snuffle its sensors towards the occasionally interesting rock. Lettering on its side reads "ARES-8."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : "MARS. PLAINS OF CYDONIA. EIGHT MONTHS LATER." Suddenly Ares-8 pauses. Its video lens WHIRRS out, fine-tuning focus, as it becomes intrigued by something OFFSCREEN -- a higher, more distant target. The little fellow almost quivers with excitement.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . TIU VALLIS. DAY A one-man ATV ROVER waits in the background, in a dry streambed, as Luke, in an EVA spacesuit, swings a clawed rock hammer against a multi-layered, sedimentary rock face. Reddish dust coats his bulky white suit. Despite that bulk, he moves easily in the light Martian gravity (1/3 Earth's). A hunk of rock breaks off, and Luke examines it more closely, holding it up to his clear faceplate. He's very happy, absorbed in this work, when his RADIO CRACKLES.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Luke, though reluctant to break off work, is intrigued.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Luke turns away, headed for the rover
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Luke, you read me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, Renee.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Luke, I just got ARES-8 on line and... Well, we think you're gonna wanna see this for yourself.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Copy that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: To REVEAL a STAGGERING PROSPECT, seen for the first time: Valles Marineris, that planet-creasing slash. So wide, so deep, it boggles the mind: on earth it would reach from New York to L.A.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sequence omitted from original script.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY The crew of Mars One - Kirov, Willis, and Cote -- have joined Luke, gathered around some display monitors. They're in NASA jumpsuits; the Hab has artificial atmosphere, enhanced gravity, and heat. All are captivated by what they see. ON A VIDEO SCREEN We see a low-angle image of an elongated, rubble and dirt- covered MOUNTAIN. Hard to tell scale, but it looks huge. What's most striking, however, is a WHITE PEAK barely protruding through the rubble two-thirds of the way along the mountain's ridgeline. Its whiteness is in clear contrast to the typical rust-orange of the surrounding rubble; what's more, this strange little peak also displays an oddly-smooth, multi-planed symmetry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cote glances at the others. They're all smirking, as if they share some secret joke Luke's not yet in on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He leans over to read a digital gauge, but Cote covers it with her hand, enjoying the tease.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They all laugh as the other shoe drops. Luke's expression is incredulous, exasperated.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Luke sits, taking over the Ares remote control from Cote. They all watch as he fine tunes the image, trying without success to coax more resolution.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The others look at him, puzzled. Luke leans in closer, with growing excitement. He points to the screen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They look at each other, Luke's excitement now leaping from one to another of them. They're almost trembling.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What the hell is that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No idea, boss.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where is it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You don't wanna know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: C'mon, what's so funny? Gimme the coordinates.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Latitude 41 degrees north, longitude 9 degrees west.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The Plains of Cydonia. So? (pause) Oh no. You're not telling me --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oui. Exactement! It's Kirov's fault, he picked today's sector.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, c'mon! We've got a scientific duty to check that thing out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Great. That's great. The first anomaly we hit, and it's gotta be in the one place guaranteed to make NASA look ridiculous... You know how many books have been written about that damned mountain?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The Egyptians put it there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, the Amazons.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, it was little green men!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And all because a couple of lousy impact craters happen to look like eye sockets. If this gets out, we'll have every UFO kook on Earth spouting off on the six o'clock news... C'mon, people, gimme a read here. Is that a cinder cone?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nah, too smooth. Too angular. Volcanic upwelling?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No fissures. No caldera.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's an upwelling, for sure. But maybe not volcanic...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Look at the color. And see how shiny it is? I could swear that's ice...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This far south?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Impossible. You can't have ice at this latitude. Not unless...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh my God.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How far away is it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sixteen kilometers northeast. Take us twenty minutes to get there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (considers a moment) Let's send a packet to Micker. Then we'll go check it out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAY AIRLOCK DOORS Slide back, REVEALING the crew in EVA suits, carrying gear. They walk over to...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The astronauts climb in through the hatch. The last one in pulls it shut behind him and locks the latches. We see Cote and Luke check their screens and press some buttons. Luke puts the rover in drive.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: R ANGLE, PULLING UP AND AWAY As the rover moves off across the rocky surface, dust kicking up from the wheels, we get our first exterior glimpse of the Mars One Base Camp. The main HAB UNIT looks like a huge tuna can with a conical top section; it connects to a separate, inflated-bubble GREENHOUSE. There's also an OXYGEN STILL, PROPELLANT PLANT, and, on the other side, a couple hundred meters distant, the massive ERV (Earth Return Vehicle), which arrived as a separate, unmanned flight. Rows of SOLAR PANELS, arrayed on the ground, and an AMERICAN FLAG on a thin pole, about man-height, complete the scene.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . EARTH ORBIT. DAY A vast, impressive, MULTI-SECTIONED SPACECRAFT is drifting majestically above Earth. The main hull displays both NASA and U.N. flag decals.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : "INTERNATIONAL SPACE STATION. MARS MISSION CONTROL ROOM (MMCR). 20 MINUTE TIME LAG." We MOVE IN towards another of the station's segments, which is dedicated entirely (as we see from more labels and insignias) to the Mars Program: Control Room, Training and Living Quarters, and a Vehicle Docking and Launch Area, where Mars Two is already positioned for its eventual flight. We hear LUKE'S EXCITED VOICE, over speakers.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: This is a truly anomalous formation. Looks like nothing we've seen so far. The structure appears to be crystalline, at least from the angle displayed by ARES-8 ...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAY On a large CENTER DISPLAY SCREEN, we see Luke and the Mars One crew, sitting around their kitchen table in the Hab, finishing lunch while taping this VIDEO MESSAGE.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks at his crew. They beam like cats who ate canaries.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (grins) We're all trying not to go too nuts up here, but -- we think there's a good chance this could be an extrusion from some subsurface, geothermal column of water. And if we're right...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...then we've found the key to permanent human colonization.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: There's an EXCITED BUZZ among the assembled TECHNICIANS, FLIGHT ENGINEERS, and SCIENTISTS. This would be a fantastic, epochal discovery.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sits at the center console, wearing a headset. He's now the Mars One CAPCOM (Capsule Communicator), and his manner is brisk, efficient, all-business. A TECHNICIAN leans in for instructions.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The technician nods, hurries away. McConnell, sharing the intense excitement of those around him, stares up at
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Tell geology and hydrology we need to scramble on this. Full-court press.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Where Luke and his crew are still smiling, well knowing the excitement their bombshell will create.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Anyway, we'are going out to take a closer look at it, try to get an idea of its composition. (checks his watch) By the time you receive this, we should be just about on-site.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . THE FACE. PLAINS OF CYDONIA. DAY The rover is a hundred meters away and moving fast TOWARDS CAMERA. We BOOM DOWN to REVEAL Ares-8, still faithfully holding its point, like an Irish Setter, with its video snout WHIRRING OUT. The rover drives up and slows to a stop nearby. The hatch door cracks open and some dust vents out. The door opens all the way and the astronauts climb out. They all look up in awe. We hear their voices ON RADIOS.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Jesus Christ...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Gleams in the sun, dazzling white, its facets as planed and smooth as if an architect had drawn them. It pierces through the topmost rubble at the near end of the big mountain -- an isolated, butte-like giant, stretching two miles from left to right in front of them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Walk towards the mountain. There's a very deep, very low, staccato tone intruding over their headsets.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As they go to their jobs, the deep, barely audible rumbling tone continues.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Anyone else hear that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah. What is it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sounds like our antenna's out of phase.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Can you fix it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, skip, I can fix anything.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Big talker. Renee, Sergei, let's break out the radar, see what this thing's made of.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . CORRIDOR OUTSIDE MMCR. DAY MULTINATIONAL CREWMEMBERS walk by, in the artificial gravity of the busy station, as RAY BECK, mid-50s, approaches from the opposite direction. Beck is the tough, crewcut, PR-savvy head of the NASA Mars Program (ID'd by his name tag), and just now he's leading a covey of U.N. AMBASSADORS on a tour. The ambassadors, of both sexes, many nations, and all races, look as excited as schoolkids.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He opens the doors, ushering his flock inside.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: ...and this is the Mars Mission Control Room, nicknamed "Micker." I understand a comm packet is incoming from Mars One Base Camp, so you may find this interesting.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAY The ambassadors enter, oohing and ahhing over the impressive array of gadgetry and personnel, and especially over the big screen. Some of them start taking souvenir snaphots. The NIGERIAN AMBASSADOR turns to Beck, whispering curiously.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: That man over there. He's in charge?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Who is surrounded by a KNOT OF TECHNICIANS, to whom he is giving quiet, precise instructions. They hover, then depart, like so many eager bees.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: BECK FOLLOWS HIS GLANCE TO MCCONNELL

direction.raw_text: Smiles indulgently at the ambassador's misunderstanding.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: No, actually, that's Jim McConnell, the CAPCOM. Our voice link to the astronauts? Jim's been with the manned Mars program since its inception. One of our real pioneers.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Will he be going to Mars, too?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ah, no. This is as close as he gets.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Luke and his crew have finished eating, and are clearing away their dishes and leftovers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cote clears her throat, gives Luke a look. The others can barely conceal their grins.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: McConnell looks at the screen, worried. What's Luke up to?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A look of relief comes over McConnell.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: McConnell winces -- Dear God, no -- as, on the screen, Kirov appears from OFF CAMERA holding a cupcake with a burning candle stuck in it, and the Mars One crew starts SINGING "Happy Birthday" to him. Loudly. And very off-key.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Soon most everyone in MMCR is singing along -- even some of the jolly ambassadors -- with the noticeable exception of Beck, who stiffens unhappily. McConnell is mortified.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Beck looks over at McConnell, who indeed is red in the face with a fake "I'm-a-good-sport" grin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Indeed, Beck's smile is thin, sour, disapproving.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Luke and the crew finish singing the song. Luke raises the cupcake in a toast.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He and his crew lean in, blow out the candle. They laugh and applaud, then wave goodbye.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Luke reaches out, turns OFF the CAMERA, and the display screen GOES BLACK. Beck turns, his gaze locking with McConnell's. He's annoyed, as if this violation of protocol were somehow McConnell's fault. McConnell returns his stare coolly.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: ...anyway, that's about it. We'll send another packet when we get back.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, right. One more thing. Today is a very special day for a good friend of ours, and I know he's there right now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now, he hates it when any fuss is made, so I won't mention his name...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...because the last thing in the world I'd ever want to do is embarrass someone like Jim McConnell.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: C'mon, you Micker weasels, sing!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sings a line, then, to CAMERA:) Hey, Ray! Take a look at him! Is he all red with one of those fake "I'm- a-good-sport" grins?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And hey, you guys, check out Ray! Does he have on one of his "This- wasn't-in-my-mission-plan" faces?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nothing you can do about it, Ray! We're a hundred million miles away!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Happy Birthday, Jimbo! Make a wish!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Catch you again soon. Take care, buddy. End of transmission.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . THE FACE. PLAINS OF CYDONIA. DAY Cote stands by a display screen mounted on the rover. Kirov has a big radar gun on a tripod, pointing at the mountain. Luke turns to Cote.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Luke doesn't understand. He walks up to look at the display screen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The deep pulsing tone continues. Luke frowns.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Well? What's under there?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (puzzled) Je ne sais pas. I... I think there's something wrong with the equipment.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I mean, it can't be right. It says... it says there's metal under there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (points) There's ten, twelve meters of rubble and sand, and then... solid metal.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That doesn't make any sense. You're reading a vein of ore.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shakes her head) No. It's under the whole mountain.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nick, could the problem with the antenna be interfering?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Could be.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Cote and Kirov) Try it closer and up the power. I'll watch the screen.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAY McConnell is taping an audio message to be sent to Mars as the rest of MMCR looks on. Beck is gone. So are the U. N. ambassadors.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Ah, we're all pretty stoked about that formation you spotted, Mars One. The folks in the geology and hydrology back rooms are going over your images and comparing them to every photomap they've got.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . THE FACE. PLAINS OF CYDONIA. DAY Cote and Kirov are close to the foot of the mountain, resetting the radar gun on its tripod. The deep vibrating tone continues. Luke is some distance away, by the rover. He looks at Willis, who's still working on the rover's antenna.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cote and Kirov are having some trouble with the switches on the radar gun. They turn towards Luke and Willis.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Willis looks at Luke. Luke nods -- Go help them. Willis starts towards the radar gun.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Nick, how we coming on that antenna?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Goin' as fast as I can, boss.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, Nick. Come show me how stupid I am. I can't get this to work.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAY McConnell is handed a slip of paper, glances at it.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Medical wants me to remind you that you're three days late on your blood tests. I know they're a bore, but you've got to get them done, or else... or else I don't know what. Just do them, okay?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . THE FACE. PLAINS OF CYDONIA. DAY Willis, Cote, and Kirov get the radar gun up and running.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Luke sidles over to the display screen on the rover.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: All set here, chief.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Okay. Crank up the juice and let's see what's in this sucker.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAY McConnell checks over his clipboard list of updates.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I think that's about it for business. But on a personal note, be advised that, ah, none of you can sing worth a damn.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: in the MMCR.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . THE FACE. PLAINS OF CYDONIA. DAY Luke watches the screen on the rover, as, by the mound...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Flips a switch on the radar gun, then swivels its muzzle slowly across the near slope of the mountain. We hear and feel the radar signal. The immediate result is that the pulsing tone we've been hearing suddenly stops.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Looks up from the display screen. A puzzled expression.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A split-second later, he gets his answer. We hear a WHOOSH, a mighty rushing of wind, as
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Why did that stop?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Starts to swirl and rise, straight up from the top or the mountain, at its center. As it swirls, the cylinder picks up debris -- pebbles, sand -- from the sediment-encrusted surface of the slopes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stare up at this spectacle, awed. A cyclone? Some kind of energy wave? They have no idea. At the moment they're too fascinated to even be scared.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ING UP - FROM THEIR POV We see the whirling cylinder rise, higher and higher, perfectly straight, until in just moments it's as tall as a skyscraper. As it rises, it gains speed and power, narrowing at its top into a conical vortex. It's sucking up so much dirt, so many rocks -- even small boulders now -- that the accumulating debris begins to darken its swirling, translucent outer "skin".
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Exchange amazed glances. Can't believe their eyes...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY McConnell still hovers by the microphone.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Honestly, Luke, if you guys don't have anything better to do with your time, I can make some suggestions to mission medical. There are worse things than blood tests.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: and GROANS from the staff in MMCR.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . THE FACE. PLAINS OF CYDONIA. DAY Luke, still staring in fascination, becomes aware of sand and pebbles flashing past his helmet. From behind. He turns.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As the nearby landscape BLURS. The vacuuming effect is becoming more general across the area. More violent.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And the spell is broken. He keys his throat mike, his lips moving, but no sound can be heard over the ROARING WIND. He waves his arms, motioning for the others to back away, towards the rover. Wind whips at their EVA suits as they obey him, retreating. Luke, backing away himself, is afraid to take his eyes off the cylinder. Then he sees that one man -- Willis -- hasn't moved. In fact he's busily snapping photographs of the cylinder. Luke hurries over to him, tugs his sleeve.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But still stares up, transfixed, like a man face to face with a cobra. Luke follows the young astronaut's frightened gaze, and his own eyes widen as he sees
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Beginning to tilt down, then coil sideways. Suddenly they're looking into the huge open "mouth" of it, as sand and rocks fly into the swirling darkness... The monstrous, gaping maw slithers down over the rim of the mountain, turning this way, then that. Seeking them. And then, with horrifying precision, it locks in on the little group of astronauts. And lunges towards them...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . THE FACE. PLAINS OF CYDONIA. DAY Luke and Willis turn, running as hard as they can towards the rover. But the suction is so great, it's as if they're held back by wires. The ground itself is SHAKING, RUMBLING, as earthquakes begin to open fissures across the plain. The ROAR of the vortex, the GROANING of the earth, are like an onrushing freight train...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In the maelstrom of flying debris, they can barely make out Cote and Kirov, still retreating, leaning back with all their strength against the suction, while staring up, aghast. Suddenly a hurtling rock, the size of a basketball, smashes into Cote's helmet from behind, crushing it and killing her instantly. Blood sprays into the wind, immediately crystallizing, in the sub-zero atmosphere, into red pellets...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As bloody hail patters against his faceplate and forearm. An instant later he sees
direction.name: direction

result.heading: LUKE, HORRIFIED, FLINGS HIS ARM UP

direction.raw_text: Snatched up by the wind, then swept past him, in a terrifying blur, arms and legs flailing, mouth open in a silent scream as he vanishes...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Abruptly opens, and he slides into a fissure. Scrabbling frantically with his gloved hands, he manages to momentarily arrest his fall, gripping the edge of the fault line, with his helmet and one elbow thrust over its lip. The air is almost solidly choked with debris, deadly boulders bound over him, and torrents of cascading sand are burying him alive...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Barely conscious, as he watches, for a horrifying final instant, as...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is sucked bodily into the black maw of the vortex, spinning and tumbling like a rag doll...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His features grotesquely distorted by the forces tearing at him, before suddenly his faceplate is sprayed with blood, and...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Willis's spacesuit explodes, his entire body disintegrating into a million bits, which instantly disappear into the hellish maelstrom. And then that maelstrom itself, just as abruptly...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Vanishes. There is an instant, ringing SILENCE, as awesome in its own way as the roaring storm itself had been...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: On the plain, as the last pebbles, released from suction, pitter down, bouncing. Swirls of dust and sand drift away, settling gently. The harsh orange landscape is once again calm, peaceful. And then, from the direction of the nearby mountain, we hear another sound: the deep bass pulsing rumble returns.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY As McConnell finishes his message to Luke.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, and I talked to Debra. She and Bobby are doing fine. Said to tell you, they're, ah, they're on their "third time through the book, page -- (glances at a note)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: page 125." They send their love and say take care of yourself. Same from us here, buddy. Till next time, then. End of transmission.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . THE FACE. PLAINS OF CYDONIA. DAY MOVING ANGLE, the CAMERA EXPLORING ground zero, as the bass, pulsing rumble continues...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: the Rover, canted sideways into a little crater, with its canopy missing, one axle fractured, but miraculously still with all four wheels...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: faithful little ARES-8, lying on its side, partially crushed under a boulder. It gives a final, pitiful WHINE, its video snout slowly extending, then dies. And finally we come to the area where the fissure had been, and see
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Leaving only a slender crease of umber sand. No sign of Luke. The pulsing rumble continues, over, as we see
direction.name: direction

result.heading: THE FISSURE HAS BEEN FILLED IN

direction.raw_text: . AERIAL VIEW. DAY An extraordinary sight, seen from high in the air, looking back down. Staring up at us from the bottom of a shallow crater, scoured clean of its aeons of accumulated silt and rubble, is a structure resembling a vast humanoid Face. The surface is gleaming white, apparently metallic. The features are suggested by intricately interlocking planes, slopes, ramps. The "eyes" -- hatches of some kind? -- are closed, and the overall expression is eerily calm, but terrible in its power, like some ancient tribal mask. We see the Face clearly for only a few beats before thick, scudding clouds OBSCURE it, but the deep, pulsing rumble continues, low and insistent...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . COCKPIT. DAY We're inside the Mars Two spacecraft, which is still in its docked position alongside the Space Station. Woody Blake, wearing a NASA jumpsuit, floats up into the cockpit in Zero-G, studying a thick manual.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He straps into the pilot's seat, staring at an electrical junction box at one end of the console.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He swings open the housing, revealing a bewildering tangle of fuses and wires. He sighs heavily, as Terri drifts up beside him, also in a jumpsuit, and straps into the co-pilot's seat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He peers into the housing with exaggerated concern. But Terri's not so easily sidetracked.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Reaching past him, she pulls out the required breaker. As he reacts, surprised, she smiles, despite her exasperation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Overhead, an intercom CRACKLES. We hear PHIL.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Woody and Terri exchange a worried look. What's wrong?
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (reads) "Problem: Hatch door malfunction, backup power fail, manual override fail. Solution: Replace circuit breaker 907B."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Okay... Piece of cake.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: God, who dreams up these nightmares?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't try to change the subject.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not! We're talking about your sister's wedding, right?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Very funny. We're talking about dancing lessons. Before my sister's wedding.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Honey, do you mind? I've got a catastrophic power failure here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Woody, we're a married couple. Would it kill you to invite me out on the floor once in awhile?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I danced with you at our wedding.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not talking about shuffling your feet around while you grab my butt. I mean real dancing. Cha-cha, rhumba, jitterbug -- WOODY Face it, honey, some couples dance, some go to Mars. That's life.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm serious. We've got two more months in this training rotation, but just as soon as we get home, we're starting lessons. If we never dance, people will think there's something wrong.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If they see me dance, they'll know there's something wrong.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You are such a lug.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Cockpit, this is Control.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Control, this is Cockpit.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Uh, Terri, they want us all back in the Station. Report to Micker.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who says report to Micker?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The little men who live in my head.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Phil, c'mon! We just started this drill.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Woody, it was Ray Beck. He told me to round up the team. Now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Sequence omitted from original script.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . MMCR. DAY A crisis atmosphere prevails. The big room is more crowded than we've ever seen it, with ENGINEERS and MANAGERS hurrying by, huddling in tense, conferring knots, or muttering feverishly into microphones. On the center screen, a giant image of Mars. A frantic flow of green numbers crawls above and below this, and the site of the Mars One Base Camp is marked in blinking red.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are staring up at this screen, appalled. McConnell and Beck stand nearby, briefing them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Looks are exchanged among the Mars Two crew.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He leans over, punches buttons on a keyboard.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Then, at 1417, the X-band continuous data stream from Mars went silent. All data -- med, environmental, everything -- suddenly stopped. While we were trying to figure out what the hell went wrong, we got a signal from the folks at the Large Array at Soccoro.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: At the same moment we lost the data stream, they picked up an intense burst of energy from Mars.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do you mean, "intense"?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (hesitates) Catastrophic.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What about the crew?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The level of energy in the pulse... didn't seem survivable.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What about the REMO? It went into Mars orbit last week. Maybe that could give us some clue.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good thinking, Woody. That's just what we tried next.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: An orange dot can be seen in its orbital ellipse around Mars, leaving a glowing electronic trail. This dot gets isolated in a viewing box, then enlarged and rotated into the computer- animated image of a small, ugly, industrial-looking unmanned cargo craft, labelled "REMO."
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: The Resupply Module checked out fine. No instrument failures, no change in status. Orbit holding steady. But there was something else. The REMO'S computer contained an uplink message -- a very faint, highly distorted transmission from Mars One Base Camp.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Someone's alive.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The message is almost indecipherable. Two teams are still working on it. You better see for yourselves.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAY FINGERS press buttons on a console. McConnell, Woody, Terri, and Phil are crowded around a monitor with Beck and two weary TECHNICIANS.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The technician nods, then gestures to his assistant who hits a play button.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Still concentrating on the audio. We managed to bring out a couple more words, but we've got a long way to go.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Show us whatever you've got.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Black for a moment, then static. Out of this static comes a faint image of Luke, sitting alone at the Hab kitchen table. He looks awful -- dried blood on his face, bloodshot eyes. The image is blurry, heavily streaked, and most of what he says is lost in waves of static.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Woody, Terri and Phil look at each other -- Oh, God.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The monitor screen GOES BLACK.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: ...make this quick... may be only ch-- (long section of static) ...to the site, when we... hit us just as we... --thers are all dead...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (following more static) ...low sound that we couldn't understand. Then all of a sudden there was this terrib... (another long burst of static) ...--stems are holding up for now, but I don't know how long I can...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAY TECHNICIAN That's it. Woody and his crew stare at the screen, stunned. This is a catastrophe almost too huge to grasp.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY As Beck leads McConnell and the other shaken astronauts down a corridor, Phil pauses, seeing...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: At her desk. TWO CO-WORKERS are trying to comfort her. One of these women looks up, and her reddened eyes meet...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks back at her, haunted.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What did Luke mean by a "low sound?"
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAY In an otherwise empty lounge, the astronauts clutch Styrofoam coffee cups. Beck stands nearby. Through a large viewport behind them, stars glitter against the inky blackness.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: McConnell and Woody exchange a glance... Woody's right.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: McConnell looks at him, nods. They're on the same wavelength. But Beck is more cautious.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Terri looks at Phil -- SIMA?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A tense beat. Again we sense the test of wills between these two tough-minded men, once good friends.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A pause with beck weighing the odds. He looks at Woody.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks at Woody, Phil and Terri, who are just as eager.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: McConnell exits followed by Terri and Phil, but as Beck starts out, too, Woody stops him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Beck looks at him a moment, nods.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: If this was a earthquake, as we're now assuming, there's usually an auditory component.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But that energy pulse they picked up in New Mexico...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Electromagnetic emission. Not uncommon with large-scale geophysical phenomena.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (incredulous) Causing this kind of damage? I don't buy it. We're missing something here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Luke must be in pretty bad shape if he hasn't blasted out of there in the Earth Return Vehicle. That thing's designed so even one crew member could fly it back to Earth.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Even if Luke was in great shape, he couldn't get home. That energy pulse would've fried the ERV'S computers.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Other than the computers, how do we think the ERV fared?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, so far our modelling says it should be in pretty good shape.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Which means it's gonna be up to us to get new motherboards, drives, and software to Mars. As fast as we can.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Whoa, slow down. It's gonna take us weeks just to analyze this data.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Right, but meanwhile, we've gotta be working up a mission plan.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Luke needs us now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Luke may already be dead. And even if he's not, it's doubtful he's going to be able to transmit again. So we wouldn't know whether it's safe to land until you were almost there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What about SIMA?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The Saturn Imaging Probe. It's going to slingshot around Mars on its way through the solar system. It could be retasked to take pictures, read radiation levels at Mars One Base Camp.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good idea Phil. If SIMA tells us Luke hasn't survived and it's not safe to land, we swing around Mars and come right back home.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes. We can design the mission to have a free return capability. It's a long trip, but if you don't land it's the best option.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We're getting ahead of ourselves. You're forgetting the bigger problem. (they look at him) The orbits are all wrong. Our first decent launch window is almost eight months from now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But we can go earlier and get there faster if we reconfigure the payload for extra fuel. We've modelled that, Ray. I've modelled it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: On paper, yeah. But those stresses have never been tested in space.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The ship can take it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I wasn't thinking of just the ship.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know the protocols for a Mars Recovery Mission better than anybody, because I helped design them. And I'm saying these guys can do it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's right, Ray. We've got a real shot.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Give me an updated mission plan by 0800 tomorrow. Then I'll put it in the works.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You'll have it by 0600.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Let's get to work.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Chief, could I have a word?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Sequence omitted from original script.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . MMCR. DAY In a quiet corner, Woody and Beck are alone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Beck's expression hardens.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Beck and Woody stare at each other. A long tense beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This stops Woody, just for a beat. Then makes him press on harder, with even greater intensity.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Beck looks back at him, his features taunt.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I've no longer got the right crew.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (surprised) What do you mean? Bjornstrom can be up here on the next shuttle.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Bjornstrom is a geologist. He's good, but not for this. My people just lost eight months of training. This is a different mission, with a different objective.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I haven't been given authorization for a mission yet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But when you are, it ought to be given the best chance for success. I want McConnell to fly right seat.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's no longer on mission status.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah. Because you washed him out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He washed himself out. He only had to pass a few more psych evaluations, but he refused to take them.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ray, he's the best pilot I ever saw, and you've got him benched at a desk.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Everybody has to pass the psych prelims. No exceptions. Jim knew that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maggie was his wife. He didn't want to lie on a couch and share her with strangers.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That was his call. But I had to make one too. It was tough as hell, but I'd do it again.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: His wife wasted away in front of his eyes. What was he supposed to do? Suck it up? Get with the program? What was his crime? That he was upset? That he cried...?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I couldn't trust him!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (his voice softer) Not in a crisis... I'm sorry Woody, but Jim lost his edge. Are you gonna stand there and tell me Jim McConnell is the same man he was two years ago? You want me to bet four more lives on that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When Maggie died, yeah, it knocked the shit out of him. It knocked the hell out of all of us. But you know and I know that he's still the best we've got. He and Maggie wrote the book on Mars. He's got more hours in the sims than the rest of us put together. Ray, we can do this. Give me McConnell as co-pilot, and we will bring Luke home. And that's a promise.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . MMCR. DAY Woody, Terri, and Phil stand at the edge of the big control room, waiting and watching, in a tense silence, as
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Beck and McConnell are huddled together at the CAPCOM's console. Other personnel have moved away, giving them room. Both men are seated, leaning forward, with McConnell listening intently, while Beck does most of the talking, very quietly. After a moment McConnell looks up in surprise. His eyes search the room till they find
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Woody looks back at him, nods: C'mon, man. Take it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is a study in conflicting emotions. But after a moment he masters his feelings, turns back toward Beck. A few more quiet words are exchanged, then Beck offers his hand. McConnell hesitates, then shakes it. Both men rise, and McConnell turns again to look towards
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who react with relief, glad that he's now a part of their crew. Woody grins, giving him a thumb's up.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: WALKS TOWARDS US, PASSING OUT OF FRAME

direction.raw_text: As he smiles. Then he starts towards them, with a new energy in his step, a new sense of confidence and purpose. And as he WALKS TOWARDS US, PASSING OUT OF FRAME...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sequence omitted from original script.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . MARS RECOVERY. DAY An infinite canopy of stars. After a moment, some of them begin to be BLOTTED OUT as
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Glides INTO VIEW. "MARS RECOVERY" (formerly Mars Two) looks much like its sister craft on Mars: a conical cockpit mounted above a "tuna can" crew Hab module.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : "MARS RECOVERY. MISSION DAY 172." The entire lower deck forms a segmented section of the hull that rotates on bearings to provide artificial gravity; we see window ports spinning past, then an American flag emblem. Behind this lower deck, in an extending network of struts, like the abdomen of a dragonfly, are the three huge round PROPELLANT TANKS. Then vast, delicate-looking rectangular SOLAR PANELS, which sweep out to either side of the ship; these also bear the dish of the earth-pointing HI-GAIN ANTENNA. And finally comes the great mass of the ENGINE BELLS, housed within a curving AEROSHELL; three hatches in the aeroshell can open to allow the main thrusters to fire through for a mid-course burn.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: R To the forward section of the ship, APPROACHING a viewport in the EVA airlock chamber. Inside, we can see Phil leaning forward, concentrating on some task...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sequence omitted from original script.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY. A BUNCH OF M&MS Are floating in mid-air, forming an intricate 3D pattern. In the EVA airlock, it's zero G. Phil, strapped into a chair by a galley counter, is just completing this weightless puzzle by placing a final blue M&M. He looks bored, sluggish. In the b.g., Terri is hunched over a microscope. McConnell emerges from the core tunnel, behind them, coming up from the lower Hab, then pushes off from the ladder, floating towards Phil. He grins, admiring Phil's obsessive handiwork.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He plucks out a couple of the M&Ms as he drifts by.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: McConnell grins, snacking on the M&Ms.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Phil looks sadly at his floating model.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: McConnell and Terri laugh as Phil starts scarfing down the rest of the M&Ms. Swooping at them with both hands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's drifted to another short ladder, and now grabs it, starts up to the cockpit, atop the Hab.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What's that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That... is the exact chemical composition of my ideal woman.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Used to be.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now what is it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A frog.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I guess now we have our answer to the effects of long-term interplanetary travel on the human mind. The answer is Phil.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (smiles) I'm gonna get an update on SIMA. It should be just about close enough to start capturing some surface images.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAY As McConnell appears in the cockpit, he sees Woody by the forward instrumentation panel, looking at a monitor. The cockpit is also zero G.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: McConnell pulls himself forward.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, Skip.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Take a look.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: completely fills the screen. Surface details are clearly visible. Something is moving down there, an amorphous brown swirl.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY WOODY What do you make of that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: McConnell pulls back from the screen, looks at Woody.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A beat. They both hope he's wrong.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They exchange a glance. Woody's right, but the thought is too terrible to dwell on. McConnell looks back at Mars.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Dust storm. Southern hemisphere, coming from the east... Big fella, too.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Headed for Chryse Planitia.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yup. Could get a little hairy just about landing time...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We'll have to be ready to move fast. Maybe even advance our ETA. Those things can cover the whole planet, and last up to a year.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When does SIMA do her fly-by?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Tomorrow morning, about 0600. That's when we find out whether we came all this way for nothing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (softly) My money's on Luke.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . EVA AIRLOCK. NEXT MORNING CLOSE ON A DIGITAL CLOCK Just turning over to read "0545."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pulls her gaze away from these numbers. Judging from her redrimmed eyes, it's been a long, anxious night. Restlessly, looking to distract herself, she reaches for a test tube of blood, straps it into a centrifuge, sets it spinning. Nearby is her electron microscope.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lies on his cot in his own cubicle, with the door closed. The lower hab has artificial gravity (AG) and McConnell can move normally. Hands behind his head, he stares at his bureau.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rests there, in its leather travel frame. Beautiful, smiling, dark-haired: MAGGIE MCCONNELL. Her face glows with intelligence and energy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shifts his eyes. The clock on his bulkhead reads "0546."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stands in the communal bathroom, still in his pajamas, a towel around his shoulders, brushing his teeth. He glances at another digital clock, which reads "0547." Shakes his head impatiently. He looks back into the mirror, then is surprised to hear MUSIC lilting incongruously over the loudspeakers: Elvis Presley's "Blue Moon."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sequence omitted from original script.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY Phil floats in through the connecting tunnel, then stops himself at a handhold. He grins, charmed by the sight of
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Like a weightless Fred and Ginger. Woody is surprisingly good at this. Enthusiastic, unselfconscious. He sweeps Terri gallantly about the little cabin, pushing off from every handy surface, even guiding her into some passable twirls and dips. She laughs, shaking her head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She grins, kisses his ear, as Phil turns, sees
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What brought this on?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Zero-G. My last chance to be graceful. Once we're in Mars gravity, it's back to shuffling my feet and grabbing her butt.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll take what I can get.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Who has now arrived, is also watching the dancing couple. A twinge of sadness crosses his features. But when his eyes meet Phil's, he shakes off the feeling and manages a smile: Aren't they something? Over the music, they hear a CHIRP from the SHIP'S COMPUTER, then an announcement.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They all look at each other. This is it! Woody spins over to a console, shuts off the music.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Attention. Incoming packet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's SIMA.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAY. MINUTES LATER The crew is gathered around a display screen. The lights are dim, reflecting up off their faces. By their expressions, we can tell the news is not good.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's a color, high-resolution satellite image of the Mars One Base Camp. Ghostly, dust-covered. No signs of life.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They all scan the screen. Phil spots something.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He grabs a stylus and touches the screen. They all look. CLOSE ON THE SCREEN Using where the stylus touches the screen as the focal point, the image enlarges. THREE LONGISH DIRT PILES appear, some fifty meters from the hab.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: McConnell gets it first.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They all realize he's right. They sit back, stunned. But then Phil has another thought.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This quiets everyone for a long moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Phil keys in some commands and data pops up onscreen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Phil uses the stylus to bring MORE IMAGES into view. The frame moves over the terrain in the direction of the Face, first in SWIFT BLURS, then slowing. Scattered rock debris come into view. The IMAGE ARRIVES where the mountain was, and they see... Debris in every direction, NEAT SPIRALS of it now, dropped uncannily into place, like some massive earth sculpture. As if - but this makes no sense -- it had been swirled towards a LARGE CRATER. The crater itself is a perfect circle. They FOCUS on the CENTER OF THE CRATER, but the image gets distorted by STATIC.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Phil tweaks the stylus, but the image won't clear up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Phil works the keyboard.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Looks deserted.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's still standing, though. So is the ERV. And look, there's the greenhouse.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We know Luke survived for at least a few hours. Question is, are there any signs of recent activity?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What the hell are those?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Graves.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hold on. There's only three. That means -- TERRI Phil -- PHIL It means Luke must still be -- TERRI No. It just means there was nobody left to bury him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Check the radiation levels.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Normal.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Go to the disaster site.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's wrong?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know. Magnetic interference?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Go to infrared.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Goes to INFRARED, reading heat, The middle of the IMAGE, where the Face is, is still distorted, refusing focus.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sit back, exasperated.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He leans closer, staring intently.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: McConnell shakes his head. But his every sense is engaged; he's like a predator just sighting his prey for the first time. We see in his eyes an utter determination to unlock this secret.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Must be a problem with SIMA. I don't see how an earthquake, six months ago, could give us this kind of distortion.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That was no quake.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then what the hell was it?
dialogue.name: dialogue
